data.text: @farfelonius *if we agree. You might not. And it’s ok.

@farfelonius All have to be met to be considered “lived expertise” (coined by Gabrielle Peters), and one privilege in these descriptors should be disqualifying. No more “I have money BUT / and”

Once we agree on that, you’ll see I’m not the person you need to ask this question to.

@farfelonius The message I wanted to convey in this cartoon is to get away from the lip service categorization of “marginalization” and get into intersectional views.
If the program is for disabled people in legislated poverty, the consultations need to be with that exact category.

@SeijPonchie If I am seeing your tweet and your cartoon, I am your audience.  I acknowledge that I have privilege, no matter what my personal challenges may be.  Now what?  Specifically now what do you want from me personally?
@SeijPonchie What is it that you want to see happen?
@SeijPonchie In fact, tech workers are already getting the “nobody wants to work anymore” treatment: https://t.co/719K8bp7jl

@SeijPonchie Definitely. I see especially amongst my peers a prevailing belief that we, with our 6-figure salaries, are the petite aristocracy and not just rather better-off serfs. It’s awfully hard to convince them otherwise.
@DanaScheider This includes those who have invested a lot in the status quo too, I suppose. So those with degrees, credentials, wealth, and careers within status quo.
@SeijPonchie It’s that old canard that those tax cuts for billionaires are gonna help me out a lot when I’m a billionaire someday.
@DanaScheider True. Those who hold a hope of success within the status quo would subvert a change.
